awd_titl_txt: Conference: Nature-based Solutions for Resilient Communities: Preparing Students to Address Grand Challenges in Ecological Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The primary objective of NSF partial support of this conference is to deepen student engagement and ownership in the Ecological Engineering discipline. NSF will be used primarily to support student activities at the 2023 annual meeting of the American Ecological Engineering Society (AEES) at the University of South Florida (USF) in Tampa, Florida. It is expected that 80 - 125 students will attend, and they will be directly exposed to state-of-the-art research, emerging dialogue about the role of diversity equity and inclusion in the engineering practice, and to an internationally recognized network of ecological engineers to inspire their development and careers in Ecological Engineering. This conference will provide critical student-targeted opportunities, including need-based housing scholarships, career development sessions, networking social events, a poster competition, and a diversity, inclusion, and environmental justice working session. 

Ecological Engineering has been defined as "the design of sustainable ecosystems that integrate human society with the natural environment for the benefit of both". Ecological Engineering incorporates the disciplines of ecology and engineering to solve environmental problems and to design, build, and restore systems that provide long-term economic, environmental, and social benefits. As a field that seeks to integrate knowledge from across diverse fields to address today's challenges, Ecological Engineering is an example of Growing Convergence Research, one of NSF's 10 Big Ideas. Conference support from NSF will allow more students to attend the conference, especially students from diverse backgrounds, and will permit more students to participate in the student design competition, network with professionals in the field, and be a part of the career and Justice Equity Diversity and Inclusion panel that will take place. By providing students with accommodation scholarships, career development sessions, presentation opportunities, Justice Equity Diversity and Inclusion engagement, and professional networking opportunities, this conference will directly contribute to Broadening Participation in STEM. Moreover, the conference theme is "Nature-based Solutions for Resilient Communities", and it is anticipated that this topic will provide a profound opportunity for students to learn how the field is critical to addressing some of the society's most pressing issues.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Overview

The primary objective of this NSF-funded conference was to deepen student engagement and ownership in the Ecological Engineering discipline. The requested funds were used to support student activities at the 2023 annual meeting of the American Ecological Engineering Society (AEES) at the University of South Florida (USF) in Tampa, Florida. Of the 201 conference attendees, 97 were students, who were directly exposed to state-of-the-art research, emerging dialogue about the role of diversity equity and inclusion in the engineering practice, and to an internationally recognized network of ecological engineers to inspire their development and careers in Ecological Engineering.

In terms of intellectual merit, this conference greatly increased the opportunities for more students from around the country to attend the conference and decreased significantly the financial burden of traveling to this conference. The award allowed students the opportunity to participate and  compete in a poster competition, network with professionals in the Ecological Engineering field, engage with professionals in a career panel, and be a part of the Justice Equity Diversity and Inclusion panel.

In terms of broader impacts, this conference hosted 201 attendees, nearly half of whom were university students studying fields related to Ecological Engineering across the US. By providing students with accommodation scholarships, career development sessions, presentation opportunities, Justice Equity Diversity and Inclusion engagement, and professional networking opportunities, this conference directly contributed to NSF’s major initiative in Broadening Participation in STEM. Moreover, the meeting theme was “Nature-based Solutions for Resilient Communities", and this topic provided a profound opportunity for students to learn how their field is critical to addressing some of the most pressing issues our society must address.

Overall, this conference provided the following critical student-targeted opportunities:

  • 34 need-based housing scholarships.
  • One career development session with panelists from the educational, engineering consulting, and public sectors.
  • Networking social events every evening.
  • A poster competition, which featured 58 posters.
  • A new diversity, inclusion, and environmental justice working session, which brought three plenary speakers and one facilitator.
